Task Parallel Library

Friday, January 23, 2015

Overview

Parallel programming is very important to know and C# does it so well. This post is all about the System.Threading namespace. More information can be found here.

Example

How do we make a line of code execute in the background on a separate thread?

 1 class Program {
 2     public static void Main(string[] args) {
 3         // Start task with the constructor
 4         var t1 = new Task( () => DoWork(1, 1000) );
 5         t1.Start();
 6 
 7         // Start task with a factory
 8         var t2 = Task.Factory.StartNew( () => DoWork(2, 1200) )
 9                              .ContinueWith( (prevTask) => DoOtherWork(2, 1200) );
10     }
11 
12     public static void DoWork(int id, int sleepTime) {
13         Console.WriteLine("Task {0} starting.", id);
14         Thread.sleep(sleepTime);
15         Console.WriteLine("Task {0} stopping.", id);
16     }
17 
18     public static void DoOtherWork(int id, int sleepTime) {
19         Console.WriteLine("Other Task {0} starting.", id);
20         Thread.sleep(sleepTime);
21         Console.WriteLine("Other Task {0} stopping.", id);
22     }
23 }
24 
25 /*
26 Task 2 starting.
27 Task 1 starting.
28 Task 1 stopping.
29 Task 2 stopping.
30 Other Task 2 starting.
31 Other Task 2 stopping.
32  */

Given the code above, how do we wait on the main thread until all the tasks are done?

1 public static void Main(string[] args) {
2     var t1 = Task.Factory.StartNew( () => DoWork(1, 1000) );
3     var t2 = Task.Factory.StartNew( () => DoWork(2, 1200) );
4     var taskList = new List<Task>{t1, t2};
5 
6     // or we could use Task.WaitAny
7     Task.WaitAll( taskList.ToArray() );
8     Console.WriteLine("Finished all tasks");
9 }
